>
>> Note that Kent Beck says, right in the first page or two of his
chapter
>> on testing in _Extreme Programming Explained_, you should not write
>> tests for things that seem simple and unlikely to break. (I'd quote
it,
>> but I'm at home right now and the book is at work.)
>
>I read it as applying mainly to simple accessors and mutators, but I
get
>the
>point.
<snip />

(Paraphrased from the FAQ...)

If your method does nothing to delegate to someone else, then testing
your method is the same as testing the method to which the
implementation delegates; therefore, test the delegate, and not the
current method. The only thing that can break is an invalid (null)
reference, and you've probably testing for that somewhere else.

It's not just for interacting with instance variables through useless
accessors. :)
